prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observations of TC2 with angular resolution of 1.5" in HCN, H13CN, HCO+, H13CO+, SiO, ....
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The proposed lines will provide information on the density structure and chemical abundances of the head of the globule and around the central source from which the jet HH399 is emanating. The selected species have different dipole moments, hence, they will trace different regions of the head and the core of the globule. Moreover, we have also included specific tracers of the shocks that could be produced by the interaction between the jet and the ambient gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The instrumental setup will provide information on the density and velocity fields, as well as the chemical composition of the globule. The selected species have different dipole moments, which allow us to probe different regions of the globule: inner core, collapsing envelope, shocked compressed layer, PDR, photoionized surface layers. We have selected a spectral resolution of 122 kHz, or approx. 0.4 km/s. A coarser spectral resolution may not disentangle with enough precision the emission of distinct velocity components , which is one of the goals of the proposal.

We have chosen an angular resolution of 1.5" in order to resolve the PDR and the photoionized layer in the transverse size, which we estimated as 2" and 4", respectively, from our previous work. The largest angular size corresponds to the radius of the cometary globule and the length of the photoionized layer.

Molecular lines, as observed with the IRAM 30m, have a typical width of 2 km/s, so that a moderate spectral resolution corresponding to a velocity resolution of about 0.4 km/s is sufficient to study the gas kinematics and resolve velocity gradients. The velocity shift between the shock compressed layer and the main body emission is of the order of 1km/s. Hence, such a velocity resolution is actually needed to separate the emission of distinct components. We expect the extended line emission from the globule to be bright, of the order of 80mJy/1.5" beam. The requested sensitivity of 3.5mJy/1.5" beam will ensure a 20sigma detection of the extended emission from the globule, and higher in the compact structures (PDR, shock), which is needed to extract the information from the wings of the line profiles.

High data rate is needed since the three spectral windows will cover simultaneously several probes of distinct regions of TC2, which are important for the project: protostellar core and its jet (HCN 1-0, H13CO+ 1-0, SiO 2-1,CCH 1-0), shock compressed layer (CS 2-1, HCO+ 1-0), PDR (C40alpha), Photoionized layer (H40alpha). A spectral resolution of 122 kHz (0.4 km/s) is needed to disentangle the contribution of these different regions. spectral averaging would not permit us to reach the goals of the proposal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observations of TC2 with angular resolution of 1.5" in CN, 13CO, C18O, CH3CN and continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The proposed lines will provide information on the density structure and chemical abundances of the head of the globule and around the central source from which the jet HH399 is emaneting. They complement the transitions requested in the first and third science goal and will permit to derive densities of H2 and molecular abudances.
The selected species have different dipole moments, hence, they will trace different regions of the head and the core of the globule. Moreover, we have also included specific tracers of the shocks that could be produced by the interaction between the jet and the ambient gas.
The continuum observations will permit to correlate the molecular abundances with the dust column density and to trace the star formation activity.
Specific tracers of the UV field are selected in this setting.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The selected lines will provide information on the density and velocity structure, the chemical composition of the head of the globule and around the protostar(s). We have included specific tracers of the UV field and the PDR (CN, CH3CN). The selected species have different dipole moments, allowing us to probe different regions of the globule: inner core (CCS, C18O), shocked compressed layer (13CO, C18O), PDR (CH3CN, CN). The continuum observations will probe the presence of prestellar and protostellar sources in the globule. Also, it will permit correlations of molecular abundances with the dust column density. The instrumental setup will provide us with a resolution of 122 kHz, approx. 0.4 km/s, corresponding to 6 elements of spectral resolution per linewidth. A coarser spectral resolution would offer only 3 elements of spectral, which is not sufficient to separate the contributions of closeby components like e.g. the shock compressed layer and the main body gas.

We have chosen an angular resolution of 1.5" in order to resolve the PDR and the photoionized layer in the transverse size, which we estimate as 2" and 4", from our previous work. The largest angular size corresponds to the radius of the cometary globule and the typical size of the photoionized layer and the lengthscale of the instabilities.

Molecular lines, as observed with the IRAM 30m, have a typical width of 2km/s. The velocity shift shift between the shock compressed layer and the main body emission is about 1 km/s. Therefore we need a velocity resolution of about 0.4 km/s to study the gas kinematics, resolve the velocity gradients and separate the contribution of the emitting components. We expect the extended line emission from the globule to be bright, of the order of 20mJy/1.5" beam at least. The requested sensitivity of 4 mJy/1.5" will permit a 5 sigma detection of the extended emission from the globule, and higher SNR in the compact structures (PDR, Shock). The continuum flux of the protostar is about 80mJy, estimated from our IRAM 30m continuum map (11" resolution).

High-data rate is needed since all the high-spectral windows will simultaneously cover several probes of the four specific,related regions of TC2 studied in the proposal: protostellar core (CCS, C18O), shock compressed layer (13CO, C18O), PDR (CN, CH3CN). These transitions complement the previous instrumental setup as it include specific tracers of the PDR and UV field, and tracers of the gas column density. A good spectral resolution of 122 kHz is required to properly resolve the line profiles, extract the kinematic information and separate the different physical components, sometimes separated by 1 km/s (only). spectral averaging would not permit us to reach the goals of the proposal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observations of TC2 with angular resolution of 1.5" in CN 2-1, CO 2-1, CS 5-4, 13CS 5-4 and continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The proposed lines will provide information on the density structure and chemical abundances of the head of the globule and around the central source from which the jet HH399 is emaneting. They complement the transitions requested in the first and second science goals and will permit to derive densities of H2 and molecular abundances.
The selected species have different dipole moments, hence, they will trace different regions of the head and the core of the globule. Moreover, we have also included specific tracers of the shocks that could be produced by the interaction between the jet and the ambient gas.
The continuum observations will permit to correlate the molecular abundances with the dust column density and to trace the star forming regions.
Specific tracers of the UV field are selected in this setting.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The selected lines will probide information on the density, velocity fields of the head of TC2 and the chemical composition in the PDR and around the central protostar(s). The selected species have different dipole moments, which permit probing different regions of the density field: inner core (CS,NH2CHO,13CS) and outflow, shocked compressed layer (CO,CS), PDR (CO,CN). We have included a specific tracer of the UV field. They complement the transitions requested in the first and second science goals and will permit to derive H2 densities and molecular abundances. the continuum observations will permit identification of protostellar cores in the globule and correlation of the molecular abundances with the dust column density. We have chosen a spectral resolution of 244 kHz, providing a velocity resolution of approx. 0.4 km/s, (6 spectral resolution elements per line)i.e. similar to that of the previous science goals, and necessary to reach our goals.

We have chosen an angular resoluion of 1.5" in order to the resolve the transverse size of the PDR and the photoionized layer, which we estimate as 2" and 4", respectively, from our previous work. The largest angular size (10") corresponds to the lengthscale of the instabilities in the neutral gas and the filamentary structures.

Molecular lines, as observed with the IRAM 30m, have a typical width of 2km/s , so that a velocity resolution of about 0.4 km/s is sufficient to study the gas kinematics and resolve the velocity gradients. Physical components with a separation of 1 km/s are observed in the head of TC2 (shock, main body gas): a resolution of 0.4 km/s is therefore required to separate their respective constribution. The extended molecular line emission from the globule is bright, of the order of 80mJy/1.5" beam or more. The requested rms of 10 mJy will ensure a 10 sigma detection of the lines, possibly higher in the compact structures, which is needed to extract the information in the wings of the line profiles. IRAM 30m continuum observations showed that the protostar has a typical flux of 100 mJy.

High data rate is needed since all the high-spectral resolution windows will cover simultaneously several probes of three inter-related regions of the globule studied in the proposal: the central protostellar core and its jet(CH3OH,NH2CHO,CS 5-4, 13CS5-4, CO), the shock compressed layer (CS 5-4, CO 2-1) and the PDR (CN2-1). A good spectral resolution (244 kHz) is required in order to properly resolve the various velocity components, sometimes separated by 1 km/s only. spectral averaging would not permit us to reach the goals of the proposal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observations of TC2 with angular resolution of 1.5" in 13CO 2-1, C18O 2-1, H2CO, HNCO, SiO, 13CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The proposed lines will provide information on the density structure and chemical abundances of the head of the globule and around the central source from which the jet HH399 is emaneting. They complement the transitions requested in the first to third science goals and will permit to derive densities of H2 and molecular abudances.
The selected species have different dipole moments, hence, they will trace different regions of the head and the core of the globule. Moreover, we have also included specific tracers of the shocks that could be produced by the interaction between the jet and the ambient gas.
Specific tracers of the UV field are selected in this setting.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The selected lines will provide information on the density and velocity fields of the TC2, as well as the chemical composition in the interface layers and around the central protostar(s). The selected species have different dipole moments, allowing us to probe thedifferent regions of the globule: inner core, shocked compressed layer, the PDR and the photoionized surface layer. We have included specific shock tracers (SiO) to trace the protostellar jet and outflow. This setting complements the transitions requested in the previous science goals; it will permit to derive H2 densities and column densities , molecular abundances in the different regions of TC2 and constrain the ionized gas density in the photoionized layer. The instrumental setting will provide us with a resolution of 244 kHz, about 0.35 km/s. Such a velocity resolution matches that of the previous science goals; it is required to properly disentangle the contributions of the physical components in the head of TC2, which are sometimes separated by about 1 km/s.

We have chosen an angular resolution of 1.5" in order to resolve the transverse size of the PDR and the photoionized layer at the surface of the globule, which we estimate as 2" and 4", respectively, from our previous work. The largest angular size (10") corresponds to the typical size of the photoionized layer, the lengthscale of the instabilities in the ionized gas and the size of the filamentary structures.

Molecular lines, as observed with the IRAM 30m, have a typical width of 2 km/s, so that a velocity resolution is sufficient to study the gas kinematics and resolve the velocity gradients. The velocity shift between the shock compressed layer and the main body emission is of the order of 1 km/s in the head of TC2. Hence, a spectral resolution of 244 kHz, corresponding to 0.33km/s, is needed to disentangle the contribution of these components. In band 6, the extended emission of TC2 is bright, of the order of 80 mJy/1.5" beam. The requested sensitivity of 10 mJy will permit detection of the usual tracers (CO, CS) with a SNR of 8, or higher in the compact structures (shock-compressed layer). Such a good SNR is necessary in order to retrieve the velocity information in the wings of the line profiles.

High Data rate is needed since all the high-resolution spectral windows will cover simultaneously probes of all the regions of TC2 : the protostellar core(s) (CH3CN, N2D+, H2CO) and its jet (SiO), the shock compressed layer (13CO, C18O,SO2), the PDR (CN, 13CN, CH3CN, C30alpha), the photo-ionized layer (H30alpha). These multi transition observations are needed in order to derive gas densities and molecular abundances. A good resolution of 244 kHz is required to properly extract the velocity information from the line wings and to separate the different velocity components, which a coarser spectral resolution(3 elements of spectral resolution per linewidth or less) would not permit.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mosaic 100"x50" of TC1 with angular resolution of 1.5" in CN 2-1, CO 2-1, CS 5-4, 13CS 5-4 and continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The selected lines will provide information on the density and velocity fields, as well as the chemical composition in the different regions of the globule: the central protostar and the inner core, the shocked compressed layer, the PDR. We have included a specific tracer of the UV field. They complement the transitions requested in the two other science goals and will permit to derive H2 densities and molecular abundances. The continuum observations will permit identification of the prestellar and protostellar sources in TC1. they will permit correlations of the molecular abundances with the dust column density. We have chosen a spectral reolution of 244kHz, corresponding to a velocity resolution of approx 0.4 km/s, hence 6 spectral resolution elements per linewidth, necessary to resolve and separate emission from the shocked compressed layer and the main body gas, and more generally small velocity shifts.

We have chosen an angular reoslution of 1.5" in order to resolve the transverse size of the PDR and the photoionized layers, which we estimate of a few arcsec, based on our detailed study of TC2. The largest angular size corresponds to the size of the filamentary structure in the ionised gas and the lengthscale of instabilities in the neutral gas.

The TC1 molecular lines, as observed with the IRAM 30m, have a typical width of 2 km/s, so that a velocity resolution of about 0.4km/s is sufficient to study the gas kinematics and resolve the velocity gradients. In order to resolve velocity gradients and separate the contributions of physical components of the globule, as close as 1 km/s like in TC2, such a velocity resolution is required. We expect line emission of TC1 to be bright, of the order of 100 mJy/ 1.5" beam. The requested sensitivity will permit detection of the core emission and compact structures with a SNR high enough to recover information from the line profiles. The continuum flux of the protostellar sources in TC1 is about 100 mJy.

High data rate is needed since all the high-spectral resolution windows will cover simultaneously several probes of three specific, inter-related regions of TC1: the central protostellar core (CH3OH, NH2CHO, CS, 13CS) and the outflow (CO), the shock comrpessed layer (CS, CO) and the PDR (CN, 13CN). Rare isopotologues will bring good constraints on the line opacity, and will help in determining the physical conditions. A good spectral resolution with 6 spectral resolution elements is required to study the gas kinematics, one of the main goals of the proposal, which spectral averaging would not permit us to achieve.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mosaic 100"x50" of TC1 with angular resolution of 1.5" in 13CO 2-1, C18O 2-1,

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The chosen lines will provide information on the density and velocity structure of TC1, the chemical composition of the different regions, including the central protostar. The selected species have different dipole moments, allowing us to probe regions of different density in TC1: the inner core (C18O, CH3CN,H2CO, N2D+) and the outflow (SiO,SO2) the shock compressed layer (13CO, C18O, SO2), the PDR (CH3CN, 13CN, C30alpha) and the photoionized layer (H30alpha). They complement the transitions requested in two other science goals of TC1, and will permit to derive H2 densities and molecular abundances, in addition to study the velocity field. The instrumental setting will provide us with a resolution of 24 kHz, about 0.35 km/s. Such a velocity resolution matches well that of the other science Goals. It is required to properly disentangle the contributions of the various physical components, sometimes separated by about 1 kms/ and to trace the gas kinematics and velocity gradients.

We have chosen an angular resolution of 1.5" in order to resolve the transverse size of the PDR and the photoionized layer, which we estimate to be a few arcsec, based on our previous study of TC2. The largest angular sise corresponds to the size of the photoionized layer and the filamentary structures in the ionized gas.

The TC1 molecular lines, as observed with the IRAM 30m, have a typical width of 2 km/s, so that a resolution of 0.4 km/s is sufficient to study the gas kinematics and resolve the velocity gradients. The extended line emission from the globule is bright, of the order of 100 mJy, or more, allowing a 7 sigma detection in the core of the globule. The requested sensitivity will permit detection of the core emission and compact structures (shocked gas layer, PDR) with a SNR high enough to recover the kinematic information in the wings of the line profiles.

High data rate is needed since all the high-resolution spectral windows will cover simultaneously several lines probing the physical conditions in the four regions of TC1 : the central protostellar core (CH3CN,H2CO, N2D+) and the outflow (SiO), the shock compressed layer (13CO, C18O), the PDR (CH3CN, 13CN, C30alpha), and the photoionized layer (H30alpha). Multi-transition observations are required to derive the gas parameters(density, col. density, temperature) and molecular abundances. A good resolution of 244 kHz is required to properly extract the kinematic information from the line profiles and separate the different velocity components. A coarse resolution of 1 km/s would not permit us to achive this major goal of the proposal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observations of TC1 with angular resolution of 1.5" in HCN, H13CN, HCO+, H13CO+, SiO, ....

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The selected lines will provide information on the density and velocity fields, as well as the chemical composition of the globule, in particular the following regions of TC1: the central protostellar core (HCO+, HCN, CCH,CS, the shock compressed layer (CS,HCO+), the PDR (C3N, C40alpha), the photoionized region (H40alpha). We have included specific tracers of the PDR. These observations will complement the transitions requested in the first and second science goals: they will permit to derive H2 densities and molecular abundances. The instrumental setting will provide us with a resolution of 122 kHz, about 0.4 km/s. Such a velocity resolution matches well that of the previous science goals. The five spectral resolution elements per linewidth will permit us to recover the kinematic information in the wings of the line profiles and to properly disentangle the contributions of the various physical components.

We have chosen an angular resolution of 1.5" in order to resolve the transverse size of the PDR and the photoionized layer, based on our previous study of TC2. The largest angular size corresponds to the radius of the globule.

Molecular lines, as observed with the IRAM 30m, have a typical width of 2 km/s, so that a resolution of 0.4km/s is sufficient to study the gas kinematics and resolve the velocity gradients. We expect to detect weak velocity gradients and velocity separation between physical components of the surface layers (gas acceleration region for region). In order to disentangle the contribution of these components, a velocity resolution of the order of 0.4 km/s, much better than 1 km/s (typical separation between the shock and the main body gas in TC2) is required. The extended line emission from TC1 is bright, of the order of 80 mJy/beam. The requested sensitivity will allow us to detect extended structures with an SNR of 20, and to extract the velocity information from the wings of the line profiles.

High data rate is needed since all the high-spectral windows will cover simultaneously several probes of distinct, inter-related regions of TC1: the central protostellar core and the outflow, the shock compressed layer, the PDR and the photoionized layer. These multi-transition observations are needed to derive the physical conditions (n,T) and the molecular abundances in the gas. One of the main goals of the proposal is to study the gas kinematics, which require a good spectral resolution. A coarse spectral resolution of e.g. 3 spectral resolution elements would not permit to achieve that goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The model of "Radiatively-Driven Implosion" (RDI) successfully accounts for the presence of long-lived molecular cores in the neighbourhood of young massive stars. RDI predicts that the stellar radiation drives the propagation of an ionization front preceded by a convergent shock front and a Photon-Dominated Region into the neutral gas. This scenario is actually incomplete. Observational, quantitative comparison are still lacking: the actual nature of the IF remains to be established dependong on the radiation field. Important dynamical interactions at the interface between the neutral and ionized phases are neglected, while they can strongly affect the cloud evolution and the conditions of star formation. The many Cometary Globules discovered in the young Trifid Nebula (M20) allow us to tackle these issues. We propose to lead a comprehensive study of two of them, in order to determine their physical and chemical structures from the central star forming cores to the surface layers, where instabilities and filamentary structures are forming. Comparison of their properties will unveil the role of the radiation field on the physical and chemical molecular gas evolution.
